Vladimir Bossicard wrote:
> > the assert:
> > - can not be ignored (exception can be ignored via emtpy try catch 
> > block)
> 
> 
> Warning!  the assert keyword may _not_ be evaluated.  Sun 
> sugests to run 
> the Java application without the "assert" option to increase 
> speed.  So 
> you cannot be sure that your application will _always_ run in the 
> 'assert' mode.  Using the _optional_ 'assert' mode to 
> validate something 
> that is _not_ optional (parameter's value) is IMO a big mistake.

That's the key distinction, IMHO.

I use assertions in my own classes, where the inputs should already have
been validated. A few seconds of typing can protect against all sorts of
errors (particularly null references!).

However, it doesn't cut the mustard where inputs can come in from outside.
So, if you're building a remoted component, or an API to be used by someone
else, or a user-interface, etc, etc, you need more explicit parameter
checking. These should throw appropriate exceptions;
IllegalArgumentException is good for APIs, probably okay for remote objects,
but pretty bad for user-interfaces.

Note that you explicitly handle exceptions, you should test that the
exceptions do get thrown; the exceptions are a stated part of your object's
"contract", after all. However, testing assertions isn't worth it. One of
the big benefits of assertions is that they let you avoid a whole heap of
stupid error checking tests ("Does this behave well if I give it a null
value?")
